titleStmt.title: interview with a university professor about the use of English and Maltese in Malta

publicationStmt.publisher: Barbara Seidlhofer, Stefan Majewski, Marie-Luise Pitzl
publicationStmt.distributor: VOICE Project, University of Vienna, Austria

availability.p: The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English (VOICE) was created by Barbara Seidlhofer (project director) and Angelika Breiteneder, Theresa Klimpfinger, Stefan Majewski, Marie-Luise Pitzl (project researchers). VOICE 1.0 XML is available for download at the VOICE Project's website http://www.univie.ac.at/voice/ under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported (CC BY-NC-SA 3.0) License ( http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0/ ). The original audio files are held at the Department of English, University of Vienna. 23 selected audio files are available as audio streams in the VOICE Online interface at the VOICE Project's website http://www.univie.ac.at/voice.
The recommended citation for VOICE 1.0 XML is:

p.bibl: VOICE. 2011. The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English (version 1.0 XML). Director: Barbara Seidlhofer; Researchers: Angelika Breiteneder, Theresa Klimpfinger, Stefan Majewski, Marie-Luise Pitzl.

availability.p: The short citation for VOICE 1.0 XML is:

p.bibl: VOICE. 2011. The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English (version 1.0 XML).

availability.p: For further information about availability and copyright permissions, please see the README file included in the download package. For further enquiries please contact the VOICE Project at voice@univie.ac.at.

notesStmt.note: This interview takes place at a university in Malta. S2, a Serbian student at the University of Vienna, interviews S1, a university professor, about the linguistic situation in Malta. The interview is conducted for S2's final thesis, which investigates language attitudes and the overall linguistic situation in Malta, particularly the relevance of Maltese and English. S2 asks S1 about the changes and developments in the past years and the reasons for the rising importance and promotion of Maltese. The recording starts after the speakers have introduced themselves.

equipment.p: Portable minidisc recorder with electret condenser stereo microphone

namespace.name: http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0
namespace.tagUsage: Used to mark a stretch of speech commonly preceded and followed by a pause or by a change of speaker. A u is, however, not required to be bounded by a pause or a change of speaker, nor does it represent a turn in a conversation analytic sense. At a minimum, a u is some phonetic production or noise made by a given speaker or a group of speakers.
Used to mark a pause either between or within utterances. Used without dur attribute to indicate a brief pause up to half a second.

Used to mark text supplied by the transcriber because the original is unintelligible or needed to be anonymized. The reason attribute is used to mark:
unintelligible
unintelligible speech anonymization
anonymized speech
Used to mark contextual information relevant to the understanding of the interaction or the interaction as such. The voice:desc attribute provides a short prose description of the contextual event.
Used to mark speech which is stressed or emphasized in a way that goes beyond regular nuclear stress.

Used with different type attributes to mark:
typeoverlap
overlaps typeonomatopoeia
onomatopoeic sounds typeipa
transcriptions in the international phonetic alphabet

Used to mark lengthening of sounds and intonation (fall, rise). The following type attributes are used to mark:
lengthening
lengthened sounds intonation
a significant change in intonation, marked with the following function attribute for:
fall
falling intonation rise
rising intonation
Intonation may or may not coincide with syntactic boundaries.

Used to mark other-continuation, i.e. whenever a speaker continues another speaker's u without a pause. Other-continuation is to be interpreted temporally and does not relate to form or content of the speakers' utterances.

Used to mark laughter and other speaker noises and non-verbal feedback.
speaker_noise
coughing
nods
shakes head
smacks lips
sniffs
swallows
whistles
wordlike
laughing

Used to mark the point at which some paralinguistic feature changes. The following attribute values are used to mark:
voice
voice quality
imitating
laugh
neutral
phone
reading
reading_aloud
sigh
singing
whisp
yawning
tempo
speed of utterance
a
accelerando l
lento neutral
neutral
loud
loudness
f
neutral
p
Used with the type attribute set to spelt to mark words or word fragments which are spelt out, i.e. words whose constituents are pronounced as individual letters.
Used to mark speech which cannot be transcribed with certainty, because it is difficult to hear or understand for the transcriber.

Used to mark a word or phrase as belonging to some language other than English. The following values for the type attribute are used to mark:
L1
the speaker's first language LN
a language other than the speaker's first language LQ
a language where it cannot be ascertained whether it is the speaker's first or other language.
Whenever possible, the voice:translation attribute provides a rough translation of the non-English speech into English.

Used to mark points where a short portion of speech has not been recorded or has been left untranscribed, whether for editorial reasons, as part of the sampling practice, or because the material is inaudible or comprises sensitive content. The following reason attributes are used to mark:
not_recorded
Not recorded speech not_transcribed
Not transcribed speech
Further information on the reason for a gap is provided within the voice:desc attribute.

namespace.name: http://www.univie.ac.at/voice/ns/1.0
namespace.tagUsage: Used to mark the beginning of a new audio track used in transcription (usually three minutes in length) and thus refers to the audio recording of the transcribed speech event.

Used to mark a pronunciation variation or coinage as described in the VOICE mark-up conventions [2.1].the VOICE mark-up conventions [2.1]. An existing word corresponding to the PVC may be provided within a commentcomment attribute within the voice:pvcvoice:pvc element. Additional phonetic transcription may be provided within a voice:ipavoice:ipa attribute within the voice:pvcvoice:pvc element.

div.u: and analyze xx so that we can see where we can plot our exams
and actually i was er i prepared some questions for you
er but er i didn't catch your name
yes so i'm in- in- investigating the present linguistic situation i am doing the a comparative study of the study done twenty years ago
er by mazzon maybe you you came across it hh and er
i want to know whether the linguistic situation has changed whether english has declined
hm okay er so er so it's a it's not er you're not only interested in maltese it's on- also in english
both languages okay as they are used in malta all right fair enough yes
yes so i would like to know what's your er opinion what's er how do you see the present linguistic situation whether something has changed erm
over the past twenty years or
er well er many things have changed
legally linguistically speaking there is a much faster change now then there was twenty years ago
erm but let me start with the bit where you said what is the present situation
now in malta okay erm most of us obviously who use maltese

erm we use english continuously for instance what i'm doing here it's all in english because the the the seminars and the conferences that er we have to participate in they are all in english okay so at the moment i would say erm that both languages are being used very frequently
but in different spheres there are certain areas where maltese is predominant

and certain areas where english is predominant but what happens is this you get institutions like the banks like er the insurance agenc- agencies erm large er departments and they carry most of their business in english
but because of this awareness on the more on on the fact they have to use maltese more
they are trying to translate most of their stuff into maltese
and since when is this happening
well largely it was er a push by the fact that we entered the er european union
okay so er this has been going on for the past er two years
oh that's very valuable to know
because it's a it's a very recent change and a very recent development
that's right yes and and and the er the er membership the e u membership has really erm produced a lot of output in translation works
which eventually erm er resulted in showing that maltese can be important you see erm
there there was a erm hh an uncomfortable attitude by some of us
why do you need such a small nation's language when you can only use it in these few square kilometres
we never we never thought that our our language could be used on a continent
we knew that it could be taken abroad with our emigrants like those in australia and in canada
okay and there are communities even in in paris maltese communities who try to keep their language alive
you understand in sidney melbourne and and er
toronto okay but we never up till two or three years ago we never thought that europe could be interested in in promoting our language
and then when they when we realized that it was going to be an official language erm
well people were delighted but apart from that economically it generated a lot of work in fact i would say the translation has grew er actually mushroomed into an industry
er erm even the university had to rush into
producing interpreters and and and translators okay
hh so would you say that the european union played a crucial role for for this language awareness
and what else er could you could you maybe think of the reason what else could have influenced er the rise of maltese in the la- in the past er let's say five
yes well if you look at the at the twenty years span that you had in mind at the beginning
erm progress contributed a lot to the growth of maltese because we actually discovered that erm we could really express ourselves in maltese
on every subject under the sky you understand and there are many publications that can pr- er that can prove this hh now the essential thing is
that most of us prefer to read a book in english right okay we can grant that hh but there are many of us who have produced books specialized books even technical books not just literature

i have been an en- er er an editor of the most important almost encyclopaedia where we have produced er a seventy-two volume encyclopaedia in which each volume treats a different subject and we've had astronomy navigation shipbuilding er gardening er flora lepidoptera
almost all subjects sports erm handcraft you know and they are all in maltese
i- it was er er a combined er work by about sixty people okay
now now now in in terms of malta when you talk about sixty people doing such a project it's a large number because we're
we're we don't have many experts understand
so you have managed to to translate all these technical terms
they just wrote them understand i can show you some of them over here
i see i said translated because hh many people stick to er english technical terms when it comes to the subject you mentioned
for example this is this is one of them because that's the the encyclopaedia that i am talking about it's about the the the maltese book
you see so it talks about the development of er the maltese book obviously it starts er from er
primitive times how people hh tried to put their ideas on stones or on clay
on papyrus et cetera up to hh the present time i've got er er well these are the books that interest me but they are related to literature hh then i've got something about er music
for example and and opera i think what this is what ah this this is the hh the sto- th- the- these are all
like that the the encyclopaedia xxx all right the history of the opera in malta
this had never been done before
so there you are er and this is only one of the volumes of course there are two one opera and two on music
okay so this was written in maltese now this is an area which traditionally was and culturally was italian earlier
er up till the nineteen century okay the er when people went to the theater they they saw plays and operas in italian
okay so culture up till nineteen century was in italian but er erm in this project we managed to to to collect all these things
yes even even astronomy for example astronomy was never written in maltese
and with this project professor [last name1] who happens to be next door yeah hh he wrote
er and described astronomy and he produced a volume like those
in maltese now i'm i'm i'm emphasizing this point because we grew up
reading all these things in english
researching all these things in english and all those people who wrote in this project their educational background was completely in english
so when we came to write er my share was maltese literature er when we came to write we had to draw from that background
and we had to put it in maltese
okay well one of my job as hh er as an editor was to make sure that the maltese keeps on being f- er fluent
er we don't we didn't want it to be too rigid
yeah and and i didn't want it to sound that it was actually being translated huh
yes so n- as natural as possible
if possible yes even when you get something technical as technical as medicine for example
okay it's er it's important that you see that er there's a continuous flow
yes and when was it published this e- encyclopaedia
well we started this in nineteen ninety-nine
and we're about to finish it this year
the last volume will be published round about september
and how is it called this encyclopaedia
kullana culturali kullana is a necklace
that's right that's right culturali well you know it's
ah good so you you can understand most of er
mhm every tenth word let's say if if the language is formal
if i listen to the news i can er
it's going to be a little bit tougher
but if the language is informal for example among students almost
do you know the composition of maltese how it's formed
i know it's a semitic language
that it's basically it come comes from er an arabic dialect
which came from sicily okay that's that's another thing
that you have to know because because the semitic element for the past thousand years
ha- the semitic element has grown with the romance element and although we have a very strong arabic structure
there is also a very strong italian stroke sicilian influence
on maltese and these have been as professor [last name2] from this university has shown these have been moving practically together hand in hand for the past thousand of thousand years
yes er is it not only in terms of vocabulary
not no- er well hm mostly it's in terms of vocabulary but there are other er
erm traces in in the morphology as well
and then i would say even in the syntax
are you talking about the pho- phoenician influence pho- er
phoenician i don't know how took er to how to pronounce it correctly hh
no no no it's it's this word i write it down for you yes do you have a pen
yes it's this one or something like that
no the the phoenicians you mean a punic element
hh well in the past people and when i say people even scholars maltese scholars used to believe
that maltese came from punic the punic
language from the phoenicians who came from the east
from van er mystic and from tarshish well anyone i'm not sure
and then they they colonized the entire mediterranean the phoenicians
hh and they even erm some of them founded cartage er in in in er in north africa and they went even up to spain
hh and malta was one of the colonies that they had okay
but this theory that maltese has derived from er punic language has no base at all
understand that is really going back two almost two not almost more than two thousand years ago
with a certain amount of certainty
er for the past thousand of thousand years you understand
erm hh i know that was a very popular whe- where do you find the the the reference to that
i can't tell you now i know it's a matter of controversy whether it was arabic or hh
yes but [S2] phoenician is er the er the- there is no scientific evidence
hh well if if you were imaginative
you say it must be that there ha- that there was er a phoenician influence yes okay but the- there is nothing
understand just like there is er as regards arabic
linguistically er er in every level that there is a lot of

i'm i'm also interested in the fact how er the maltese see their language today hh er whether they became more aware of of its importance of of their as a part of their identity hh whether has something change changed

most of us are are are very pleased and very happy when we are a- when we are abroad and we and people tell us malta where is that and you tell them where it where malta is do you have a language yes we have a language and we are proud
because we have our own language
and it is er a complete language but when we are here there are people who hate the language

and they prefer to express themselves in english and they prefer to write in english and people start saying that maltese is difficult to write hh and then they ignore the fact that an f sound in english can be written with a p h or an o u g h

and yet they say that it's difficult and er they are very proud when they send their children in formtry secondary school and they start learning german and then you get er erm erm a a cluster of consonants there and they have only one sound and it doesn't matter that they that very often they mis- er er get a lot of mistakes there
but that's a effort in language so that's okay but when it comes to maltese hh if they have something that they can't tackle in the orthography then all hell breaks lose
this is the attitude because it's it's ours so we don't erm er
we don't really take good care of it
okay can you pause it a little

div.u: do you think that the pupils perform worse now in the last couple of years
well you can't really say because er numbers have have grew so much you know erm hh i think as as as regards standards we still maintain our standards

that we had in the past the difference is this in the past say thirty forty years ago there were very few students studying er further education when i was at this university as an undergraduate there were practically there were barely five hundreds students in all
the faculties hh today er it it's reached almost ten thousand people
yeah you see so even though we have a lot of people there are still those few who are really brilliant and this goes
you see you can find these cases throughout the the the the hh school life
right from the primary up till the tertiary level up yeah hh erm er but obviously since you've got more numbers then you're going to find that there are more failures
and the and the few were good are still few
yeah the so i i don't think that standards have gone down or anything like that

hh er what we can say is this there are certain factors that contribute to people's not concentrating enough on their work er well with with er with all these things going around us people want to work well they want to have a second job they want to have a part-time job while they are studying these are these are relatively speaking new ideas
er er and malta traditionally is student was a student and and and he doesn't go to work if he is forced to go to work then he has got to quit school
but now you can find people going to work and to school
and some of these students over here they might even have more then one job
and you can even actually find more stu- erm some students who've got hh better things hh than you have see
i'm i'm i'm this is a very old version but
some of my students have got a very
erm and i wouldn't dream of spending as much money
as they do on such things for me this is something that i have to use
er you you see there are these things so i i think they they they they disrupt a little bit er from from studying still i wouldn't say that standards have gone down drastically
hh you still get those few who are the cream of the lot
and they perform very well and they might be the ones who eventually er reach a certain genius level er you understand
yes i'm more interested into hh er level of er languages of competence in in er maltesan english
what do you think about that has the level of english declined according to you in the last couple of years
no i do- i i i wouldn't say
on the basis of the results you have
on the basis of the results erm hh all right on the basis of the results
yes because i've just finished examining a lot of composition works in english of our erm fifth-formers
and i've discovered a lot of good stuff in that
hm and er and er so so you can still find an element that's very good
now people normally er say that standards in english have go- have gone down
yes and you tell them erm what's your proof because er look that's what we are finding people are not writing er er they they are not producing or performing very well
it's true that the quality of what they're producing is different hh but then they're very fluent in er speaking english
and they comm- can communicate so you can have one at a er er one phase that that that could be very low hh and that would be a- and the reason for that could be that people are not reading enough
but this is a a a universal problem okay
prefer to look at the internet and the internet as you know does not really present
very good language okay er but they wouldn't pick a book like this
okay to try and understand for example the roots of a nation
all right th- er er er er it it hh they don't read so a lack of reading okay can produce er or can lower the standards in in written language
and do you think that er erm a rise in maltese can also influence er
no no no i do- i don't think so i i
principle that if you are good in one language some of the competences in that language can be transferred onto another language
so er if you are well disposed at er learning a particular language okay i i would say that your mental composition and now i am talking psycholinguistics
all right erm you can you can actually perform good in another language if you put your mind to it

okay maltese and english are are are very different okay hh there could be interference yes er and we try to control interference and that is where we partly fail because we are not really controlling now i am talking about both languages because you can get
english influence in maltese but then people don't really mind that english influencing maltese but they are worried if maltese influences english
i've been to a couple of schools both private and church and even to p- er to a public school
yes and er hh i saw that for example teachers er use both languages when er
yes because the national minimum curriculum permits them to do that
from one language to another as long as you

and do you agree this er curriculum is effective on maintaining bilingualism in terms of that english and maltese are taught and er promoted equally or do you think that english is still more promoted than maltese
hh well let's let's start from the fact
erm should education promote bilingualism yes it should
because that is part of our of our society that's part of our make-up we've always had bilingualism here i would even go so far as to say we always had multi- -linguism -lingualism
because there were always somebody er governing us
and they brought their language and then there was the er international language latin and the cultural language italian
so when we were under the spanish for example we had spanish latin italian sicilian and maltese
of course maltese was never part of the administration was never part of politics was never found in er in in in high places
okay but this is the situation hh erm er during the time of the knights of malta
you know about the knights of malta okay there were many languages here
seven or eight languages coexisting with maltese
okay so really we had our er hh erm erm european union over here
with the knights because they were
all from different parts of europe erm then when the british came well er there was the question of english and italian
at the beginning of the last century
that's right and er er so there was always this it's part of our lives and we realize that we that w- in order to survive in this world we need english hh and and all of us love english
and what's the reason people like english in malta
what's the reason why people like english in malta
because it is it is the language that is going to help us live with other nations
all right if i want to promote hh er maltese literature i have to do it through english i have to make sure that i translate and i do translate some some some literature you know
no for survival i would say and not because because
you have to survive well commerce and trade and politics and legislations
all these have to be done in in english when you are
when you are communicating with people
er er er well it is contact because everything is contact isn't it
today maltese has a special place in terms of that it is promoted and it's present in those hh higher places as you put it
that was never the case before
and that's why maybe the people now erm are more aware and er
y- y- yes w- we are we are very conscious now more because
er you see when you are at home and you do a mistake you don't really mind because you know that it's only your family who are going to notice a mistake
but once you are out of home and you are a- a- and you make a mistake then you don't want the whole world to know that you are making a mistake
what we'll do in case we are trying to think locally so that globally or continentally we take care of everything
this is a process that that that needs er to go very gradual and i think education
through the curriculum through encouraging bilingualism is taking care of this

all right now er is it having an effect on the performance of the students yes it is obviously because there are some some students who who do not often make a distinction between english and maltese when they use the language
and it is very very frequent that you find some people starting in one language and the same sentence they finish it in second language in in another language
you understand er this is something that goes on and on
all right so you have to switch from one language to another
but but it is only when we are together when we are maltese xx
okay if you were a maltese i'd probably be doing the same thing when when i am talking like this but but you are not maltese so i stick to one language
understand hh er this is this is it it's part that is code switching is part of our of our er
there are people who who continue this even at home
all right erm i try to keep the two languages distinct because i believe that each language in malta has got has got its own function
okay erm mostly what happens in this university has to take er has to take place in english okay
except of course when you are teaching er maltese or maltese literature er et cetera all right
erm but then out of this university you are going to find a lot of er maltese being used hh
but then there are there are the common things for example one i go to the bank the first thing that i hear is an english word yes
no instead er the the malt- er instead of the of having the maltese equivalent which we do have
you understand so er even when when somebody phones you up hello good morning
that's the first thing you hear okay and then when i say bon yum
erm but but but it's not always the case most departments use english continuously
yes i o- i when i came to malta i have noticed that many people like maltese is present all over i i
i i hh experienced that people a- -ddressed me er in maltese many times many times much more than in english
yeah so i i would have accepted er more english
but do you do you speak aha but do you speak to them in in english
yes of course afterwards they realized that i'm a fo- er foreigner and they stick to english of course but

u.seg: and then they reverted to english yes

div.u: what i wanted to say is that i had expected more english from what i heard er about malta and from what i had read before i came
so i think that er maltese is really rising and
erm yes there is it depends what you are talking about is it
is it excuse me is it er the written language that you are talking about then the written language there is no doubt that
well i i would say maltese is very very very frequent
yeah much more frequent than it was
maybe because again it depends where you were in certain areas
sliema area for example up to bugibba
er you can find more er more er english being spoken even in the past understand but then in the in the in the er rural areas you get
i live in sliema for the mo- at the moment er with a foreigner family
and the they came to malta twelve years ago and they told me even in sliema people used to speak much more english than before
and now they realize and they notice that maltese is much more frequent
because there is another bec- yes because there is another fact there er i think we started with this
people realized that maltese could earn you some money understand

so it's better if you if you acquaint yourself a little bit maltese right and then you can make some good money with maltese and that is another use but but i agree with you that there is more awareness about the national identity and the cultural identity of the language the impact of joining e u has also er been on this factor because because we er enjoyed the idea of having a diverse wide continent with different languages
and that we are actually contributing for this diversity
so this is er er another factor and people are are are very proud to to contribute this
still some attitudes die hard you know they er er it's not very easy to to change attitudes
in ge- in general in general i would say that maltese the importance of maltese has
maltese has developed a lot and it's developing very fast okay erm i wouldn't say that english is suffering
if english is suffering it could be because people are reading less
okay but again i don't really believe that the standards of english are are are very low they could be decreasing because there are larger numbers understand
but it doesn't necessarily mean er that the two languages are really detrimental to each other
no i don't think so because where you use maltese you don't use english
you see for example if i am writing this paper i have to write it in hh erm er in english
when i communicate with teachers it's in maltese that i communicate with teachers
you see so there is no no certainly no
er interference in that but but again we're doing you over a specialized area here right
but er in in in in common day language people do swap one language with another
and what you said about er literature in the last er two hundred years
it would be really valuable to have that as you said the it proves that it's a language
er that maltese is a language yes
i i'll tell you what i i'll i'll m- i'll make a photocopy of this
is there anything else you want to ask
okay so let me make you a copy of this article
i can leave you my email as well if if you
so that you know who visited you and i will definitely contact you and tell you
don't hesitate even if you have
when i finish my thesis i will inform you about it and
i will send you a part where
all right but even if you have er er problem with er
anything that is related to to to maltese okay
thank you thank you very much
please don't don't hesitate to contact me is this too much for you shall i switch it off
thanks oh thank you very much
er pictures i didn't pho- i didn't photo- the
photocopy the picture now that's two thousand and four published
okay so er xxxx paper okay
envelope do you need er an envelope
if you have one if you don't have it doesn't really matter

incident.voice:desc: S1 leaves the room; S2 looks through copies; S1 returns with the promised envelope

div.u: thank you so much will you be coming to [place1] maybe
uhu because er and at the moment there are some of our friends from [place1] er because we've done er a project together
on how parents can contribute erm in the education of of their children
okay and i've been twice in [place1] on to different conferences
no this was about education yes
so next time if if you come to [place1] please don't hesitate to contact me
though i am originally from [place2] i'm studying there
aha and what do you intend to do when you graduate
oh maybe to to do my post- er -graduate studies i still don't know to be honest
i have to finish my m a thesis first
this is what you are doing i see
so i am glad i i came here
yeah erm as i said if you have any problems you can always contact me and even er you said you're going to stay here for five more days
well if you remember anything that you want to discuss further
you can always come here but
but i think it's better to be phoned before because i might not be here
thank you very much it was a pleasure meeting you
